Thanks Jeff, Picbreeder was a lot of work to put together!

In answer the y=
our question, remarkably, everything you see on the 
site started ultimatel=
y from complete randomness (i.e. a completely 
random population of minimal=
 NEAT CPPNs).  Every picture is the 
result of nothing more than one or mor=
e people selecting images they 
liked from a group of candidates.  So no, t=
hey do not start from any 
given pictures.  

I believe this point deserves=
 emphasizing.  To me, it's pretty 
amazing that all of these pictures start=
ed from nothing.  There was 
never an artist and no initial designs.  It's =
a genuine testament to 
the power of evolution to produce complex results. =
 In fact, it is 
one of the few demonstrations of this supposed evolutionar=
y 
capability (i.e. towards higher complexity and organization) that is 
ac=
tually intuitive to the naked eye.  For example, check these out:

http://w=
ww.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/picbreeder_collage.png   

(press "zoom" in your br=
owser to see it at highest quality- browsers 
default to a worse resolution=
)

Furthermore, it shows the power of CPPN encoding that it could be 
steer=
ed to such a variety of recognizeable objects through nothing 
but what is =
in effect a pop-15 greedy GA.

Of course the reason it was possible is beca=
use humans are doing the 
evaluation- which yields another lesson: The fitn=
ess function in most 
evolutionary computation is a liability against getti=
ng to high-level 
complexity.  There are deep reasons that human evaluation=
 is actually 
more analogous to what happened over natural evolution than a=
ny other 
type of evaluation scheme we run on computers.  We are often misl=
ed 
into believing that interactive evolution is less "natural" than 
norma=
l EC.  Actually, the opposite is true.

The exciting thing is that this exp=
eriment just started.  Who knows 
where it is going to go?  We didn't know =
we'd be seeing cars and 
sunsets but the system and its users (who deserve =
a lot of credit) 
offer constant surprises.  Hopefully people will branch f=
rom some of 
the deepest lineages (i.e. most complex, having been through t=
he most 
generations) to go even farther down the path that they are going.=


ken

=
> > Subject: [neat] Picbreeder: World's Largest Collaborative 
Interactive
=
> > Evolution Experiment
> > 
> > Hi Everyone, 
> > 
> > I am pleased to an=
nounce the opening of Picbreeder, a massive
> > experiment in collaborative=
 interactive evolution, which happens 
to
> > be based on NEAT:
> > 
> > ht=
tp://picbreeder.org
> > 
> > Picbreeder is a unique online service that all=
ows users with no
> > artistic experience to evolve pictures in collaborati=
on with each
> > other. The technology behind Picbreeder is a novel NEAT-ba=
sed 
Genetic
> > Art applet that is integrated into a massive growing "tree=
 of 
life"
> > that never ends. Anyone who evolves a picture they like can =

publish
> > it to the world and thereby permanently add their creations to=
 the
> > ever-expanding tree of life.
> > 
> > What makes Picbreeder partic=
ularly powerful and unique is that you
> > can *branch* from the published =
work of any other user that has 
come
> > before.  In other words, you do n=
ot have to begin from scratch.
> > Instead, for example, if you want to a e=
volve a face, you can 
branch
> > from one of the many published faces and =
explore an infinite 
number
> > of variations from that starting point.
> >=
 
> > Perhaps most intriguing is that we do not know what is possible to
> =
> evolve.  As lineages are built upon lineages, complexification in
> > NEA=
T means that images can theoretically become more and more
> > complex.  Th=
us, in theory, anything is possible.  In this sense
> > Picbreeder's users =
are pioneers, exploring collectively a space 
that
> > has never been exhau=
stively explored and discovering together
> > creations that no one of us c=
ould have discovered alone.
> > 
> > I hope that you will decide to join us=
 on Picbreeder as we explore
> > this space.
> > 
> > ken
> >
>
